content.title: The Whippet Coffee, South Africa on New York time

introduction.small: Near Johannesburg, The Whippet Coffee gives coffee some class, drawing inspiration from Brooklyn's coffee houses.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Whippet Coffee, South Africa on New York time

paragraphs.text:
The decoration is stylish and stripped-down, with an industrial feel, large windows and ceiling pendants, wooden furniture, plants scattered around, a brick terrace… In Linden, small city close to Johannesburg, The Whippet Coffee ticks all the right boxes of New York trendy coffee houses. This unabashed hipster side is not limited to the decoration: the establishment carefully selects the coffee and tea added to the menu, and it brings a world of pastries to the counter. So much so that there is little room left for anything else but muffins, croissants, peanut butter pies and other enormous homemade cakes sliced all day long! From breakfast onward, coffee lovers order americanos, served with scrambled eggs, grilled sausages and potato cakes. Others will favour afternoon teatime, best enjoyed comfortably sitting on a sofa.

The Whippet Coffee
34 7th Street
Linden
Randburg 2104

+27 (0)61 512 1373

https://thewhippetcoffee.com

Menu: coffee from 23 ZAR

content.title: A truly unique brunch at Salvation Café

introduction.small: In a warm and relaxing setting, Salvation Café presents a very original menu for breakfast, entirely homemade.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A truly unique brunch at Salvation Café

paragraphs.text:
Written in chalk on a black board, you will discover Salvation Café's slogan: "Non-pretentious food, prepared with love". In the heart of the trendy Milpark neighbourhood in Johannesburg, this coffee shop is packed at brunch time, most patrons making the trip to enjoy the house speciality: eggs. Benedict with or without smoked salmon and avocado, Florentine with or without spinach… there is something for everyone.
Take a seat on the terrace, genuine haven of rest, with iron-wrought chairs displayed around the fountain and bench seats covered with large blue pillows. The perfect setting to enjoy a homemade ice tea (pineapple, ginger or lemon). In addition to the eggs, the menu offers a large selection of dishes to please the palate. Choose the “Salvation Duo”, eggs Benedict with spinach, bacon and homemade cereal bars, or the toasts with mushrooms in cream and a poached egg, depending on your taste. The best way to start off the day with a hearty breakfast!

Salvation Café
44 Stanley Avenue
Milpark
Johannesburg 2092

+27 (0)11 482 7795

www.salvationcafe.co.za

Menu: from 138 ZAR

content.title: Tashas, between cafe and fine dining

introduction.small: With a hybrid concept in Johannesburg, Thashas is a modern and laid back cafe that offers fresh and innovative recipes for breakfast, lunch, or just a gourmet break.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tashas, between cafe and fine dining

paragraphs.text:
From the moment you step in, the rows of pastries exposed under the glass windows really catch the eye. Above your head, old books have been customised and turned into chandeliers. In the Rosebank neighbourhood of Johannesburg, Tashas is always packed, just like the 9 other restaurants of the franchise in town. They are all themed and, here, influences hark back to Manhattan's trendy cafes. From the stylish decoration, stripped-down and bright, to the huge black counter, everything screams New York. Food lovers come any time of the day for brunch, lunch or just a snack. The very varied menu takes on the healthy-eating trend, with high-protein smoothies and a “citrus sunrise”, a citrus salad with bananas, caramelised oatmeal, honey yoghurt, pistachio and rose syrup. The most ravenous ones will gladly indulge in the Tashas hotchoc, chocolate-based hot drink served with marshmallows. The perfect snack.

Tashas
Shop No. G28, The Zone, Oxford Rd
Rosebank
Johannesburg 2196

+27 (0)11 447 7972

www.tashascafe.com

Menu: snacks from 50 ZAR

content.title: An excursion to a diamond mine

introduction.small: Just an hour from Johannesburg, discover the Cullinan Diamond Mine on a guided tour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: An excursion to a diamond mine

paragraphs.text:
Considered to be one of the largest and most productive diamond mines in South Africa, the world's largest diamond was found here, measuring 621 grams or 3,106 carats. Nicknamed the 'Cullinan', it was discovered in 1905 and given to King Edward VII of England. A quarter of the gems from around the world comes from this mine and serves in industry or in jewellery. The galleries can reach 500 to 700 metres deep.

Created in 1992, Premier Diamond Tours allows you to explore one of the only mines of the region still open to the public. There are 14 well-qualified tour guides who will share their knowledge of this unique place. During your two-hour expedition, you will discover the techniques used by miners and participate in a lottery to try to leave with an exact replica of the famous Cullinan.

Cullinan Diamond Mine
1 Bank Street
Cullinan 1000

+27 (0)12 734 0081

https://www.cullinan-tours.co.za/

content.title: In the footsteps of Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela

introduction.small: Born in 1918 in the Cape province, Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela left for the economic capital of the Transvaal, Johannesburg, at a very young age. A look back at a larger-than-life man of peace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the footsteps of Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela

paragraphs.text: Upon the death of his father, Nelson Mandela was adopted by the regent, Jongintaba who, a short time later, wished to arrange his marriage, which Mandela refused. He then fled to Johannesburg, ready to oppose the traditional customs of his people. In 1943, he joined the African National Congress, led by Alfred Xuma who, for the first time, fought not only against racial discrimination, but for political power. In his fight against apartheid, Mandela committed acts of bravery throughout the city where many monuments have been dedicated to him. The Nelson Mandela bridge is South Africa's largest cable-stayed bridge and crosses over 40 railway lines. To the north, Constitution Hill was once home to this famous activist, and to the south, the Apartheid Museum looks back at the phases of the establishment and the later challenge of this discriminatory separation. At the heart of this struggle, the Soweto district still remembers the violent riots of June 1976 and preserves the red brick house of this admirable man, father of the modern South African nation.

content.title: Cradle of Humankind: a remarkable paleontological site

introduction.small: An immense 50,000-hectare area, declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1999, this is one of the most important palaeontological sites in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cradle of Humankind: a remarkable paleontological site

paragraphs.text:
Excavated since the 1930s, this site has already delivered precious treasures from the dawn of humanity, including remarkably preserved Australopithecus skeletons, the oldest dating from about 3.5 million years ago, making it among the oldest humanoid remains ever uncovered.

Excavations continue and discoveries are made almost daily here in the Sterkfontein Valley, about a half-hour drive from Johannesburg. A prehistoric site of major importance in the world, it is composed of some forty limestone caves, including the Sterkfontein, one of only two that you can visit, where nearly a third of the hominid fossils in the world have been discovered.

Declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO, the Cradle has an entirely refurbished visitors centre and now offers you an educational centre, as well. Take a stroll and visit the galleries and underground streams. Academic experts will show you current dig sites via guided tours, letting you peek inside and examine the rocky walls.

Cradle of Humankind
Gauteng

+27 (0)11 085 2500

www.gauteng.net

content.title: Radisson Blu Hotel: perfectly located

introduction.small: A timeless and comfortable hotel a few minutes away from the main sites of Johannesburg.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Radisson Blu Hotel: perfectly located

paragraphs.text:
Opposite the Sandton Conference Centre and less than a ten-minute walk to Nelson Mandela Square, surrounded by shops and restaurants, this property offers many surprises.

Classical or contemporary, the 290 rooms and suites, with very different themes, are decorated in shades of warm African colours, accented with wood. If you want to enjoy a private terrace, a wine cellar, and the services of a personal butler, opt for a suite.

Of note, the Vivace restaurant, with beautiful views of the city, serves an amazing buffet of not less than 120 dishes. The hotel also features a lovely panoramic terrace with an outdoor swimming pool and bar on the roof, a fitness centre, and a wellness Spa. The perfect hideout for total relaxation.

Radisson Blu Hotel
Daisy Street & Rivonia Road
Johannesburg 2010

+27 (0)11 245 8000

https://www.radissonhotels.com/en-us/hotels/radisson-blu-johannesburg-sandton

Rooms: from 1,564 ZAR

content.title: Sakhumzi: an authentic experience

introduction.small: The best address for a delicious, hearty lunch in Soweto.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sakhumzi: an authentic experience

paragraphs.text:
Sakhumzi awaits you on the famous Vilakazi Street, the heart of the historical and cultural centre of Soweto and the only street in the world where two Nobel Peace Prize winners used to live: Desmond Tutu and Nelson Mandela. A former shebeen, an illegal bar during apartheid, it is now a traditional restaurant that is very appreciated by the population of the district.

On the menu, some Zulu or Xhosa dishes such as mielie pap (mashed maize), morogo (wild spinach), umleqwa (chicken-based recipe), chakalaka (vegetable and leguminous-plant stew) dombolo (a steam-baked bread), and umngqusho (maize served with beans), one of Nelson Mandela's favourite dishes. Alternately, you can opt for grilled meats. Lunch at the picnic tables on a shaded terrace outside, and take in the ambience of this famous district.

Sakhumzi
6980 Vilakazi Street
Soweto 1804

+27 (0)11 536 1379

http://sakhumzi.co.za

Menu: around 250 ZAR

content.title: Fairlawns Boutique Hotel & Spa: a getaway in Joburg

introduction.small: A 5-star refuge, highly appreciated by well-known personalities travelling through town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fairlawns Boutique Hotel & Spa: a getaway in Joburg

paragraphs.text:
Located in Sandton, in the suburb of Morning side Manor, this property purchased from the Little Brenthurst Trust was originally part of a four-hectare estate with stables, horses, and large impeccably mowed lawns.

Now an award-winning boutique hotel with 40 suites and villas, it is decorated in a classic style, complemented with beautiful objects that make for welcoming and comfortable rooms. Appreciate the antique furniture, fine quality fabrics, perfectly upholstered armchairs, and working fireplaces. This little gem, also equipped with a swimming pool, is surrounded by a garden with huge mature trees, where many birds live. There is a restaurant, a library, a gym, and a Spa that takes its inspiration from Bali.

The reception staff is at your disposal to help you organize your stay and any excursions to the many sights of Johannesburg and its region that you may wish to undertake.

Fairlawns Boutique Hotel, Villa Residence & Spa
1 Alma Road
Sandton
Johannesburg 2191

+27 (0)11 804 2540

www.fairlawns.co.za

Rooms: from 5,000 ZAR

content.title: Kitchener's Carvery Bar: a trip back in time

introduction.small: The perfect place for a glass in an authentic setting with a cool ambiance.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kitchener's Carvery Bar: a trip back in time

paragraphs.text:
After a long day, here at Kitchener's you can enjoy homemade cocktails with music piped in the background. This bar has been open on the first floor of a two-story Dutch house for slightly more than a century.

With period decor, the place is where the trendy youth of Johannesburg meet up and a must if you're looking for a quirky bar open until all hours of the night. Located in the Milner Hotel in the heart of downtown Johannesburg, Kitchener's has cotton tapestries, embossed tin ceilings, and mosaic floors that make the bar feel like a time capsule. Known for its refreshing eclecticism, it enjoys a musical reputation that lives up to its impressive history. You can enjoy cocktails in the bar or dance to live tunes many nights.

If you're lucky, you may get to see an improvised session by a well-known artist come to ‘slum it up', away from prying eyes.

Kitchener's Carvery Bar
71 Juta Street
Johannesburg 2000

+27 (0)11 403 0166

www.facebook.com/BarKitcheners

content.title: Satyagraha House: a meeting with history

introduction.small: A residence still steeped in the spirit of Ghandi, its most renowned resident.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Satyagraha House: a meeting with history

paragraphs.text:
Walk in the footsteps of Gandhi in this beautifully renovated guest house, recently redone by the Voyageurs du Monde travel group.

More than a hotel, it is above all a place of memory and a museum, now classified as a Johannesburg historical heritage site. Gandhi lived in this house for more than a year between 1908 and 1909, with his friend Hermann Kallenbach, an architect. Between these walls he developed his modern concept of passive resistance, or Satyagraha in Sanskrit. The seven rooms have uncluttered decor-you will remember the simplicity in which the Mahatma wanted to live.

Some rooms are located in the historic house, called the 'Kraal' in reference to its architecture, inspired by a traditional African farm, others are in the cottage or in lovely buildings of brick with bay windows that open onto the garden. Here, in keeping with the spirit of yesteryear, no televisions are to be found and there is no pool, but you can enjoy introductions to yoga or meditation.

Satyagraha House
15 Pine Road
Orchards
Johannesburg 2192

+27 (0)11 485 5928

www.satyagrahahouse.com

Rooms: from 3,080 ZAR

content.title: Four Seasons Hotel Westcliff: an exclusive choice

introduction.small: An establishment that confirms the renaissance of the new Johannesburg.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Four Seasons Hotel Westcliff: an exclusive choice

paragraphs.text:
In a landscaped area covering three hectares, the Westcliff Hotel has undergone an extensive renovation with completely redesigned spaces, while restaurants, bars, swimming pools, and a new Spa were added.

A magnificent collection of carvings made from the remains of drilling sites is a tribute to a region marked by its long mining history. In total, 375 original works signed by renowned artists such as Helmut Starcke, Obie Oberholzer, Gawie Joubert, Saral Petrus, Diana Hyslop, Lehlogonolo Mashaba, Louis Olivier and the team Arlene Amaler-Raviv and Dale Yudelman are exhibited in 117 rooms, suites, and public areas. To brighten up your taste buds, two restaurants are here: Flames has a menu influenced by barbecue, and is very rooted in the culture of the country; and the View, also designed as an art gallery.

Four Seasons Hotel The Westcliff
67 Jan Smuts Avenue
P.O. Box 2700
Saxonwold 2132

+27 (0)11 481 6000

www.fourseasons.com/johannesburg/

Rooms: from 4,124 ZAR

content.title: Golf: perfecting your swing

introduction.small: Golfers have several courses of exceptional quality available in Johannesburg and surrounding areas. For a full-on resort, head to Sun City where you can continue golfing amidst many other activities.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Golf: perfecting your swing

paragraphs.text:
Johannesburg boasts excellent golf courses. If you are a beginner, or in need of practice greens, opt for the World of Golf just north of Johannesburg, in Midrand. Open until 9:00 p.m., you can discover the different areas of their golf 'universe', including the 'world of bunkers', the 'world of fairways' and the 'world of chipping'. You can also take a trip to Kyalami Country Club that also has excellent golfing options.

Alternatively, there is Sun City, a two-hour drive from Johannesburg, near the rugged mountains of Pilanesberg. Part resort and part amusement park, the site is a true tropical paradise, combining 22 different landscapes that are home to more than 1.6 million plant species, 70,500 sqm of water, an entertainment centre, two golf courses, a fitness centre, and several hotels, including the legendary Palace of the Lost City, the most spectacular of all. The legendary South African golfer Gary Player designed both of the golf courses here.

World of Golf
Corner Woodmead Drive and Maxwell Drive
Johannesburg
Gauteng 2148
+27 (0)11 545 8600
https://www.facebook.com/WorldofGolfSA/

Kyalami Country Club
433 Maple Rd
Kyalami AH
Midrand 1684
https://www.kyalamicc.co.za

Gary Player Country Club Golf Course
R556
Sun City 0316
+27 (0)14 557 1245
www.suninternational.com/sun-city

content.title: The Butcher Shop and Grill

introduction.small: For meat lovers, this is a South African institution.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Butcher Shop and Grill

paragraphs.text:
If you like very tender and delicious steak, a stop here is a must. Installed on Nelson Mandela Square in Sandton, you won't be alone in a restaurant that seats 600, but an army of waiters will take good care of you. The setting is classic, with an emerald green ceiling, wooden chairs, and crisp, white tablecloths.

The owner, who comes from a family of butchers, knows what he sells. The perfectly selected cuts are cooked to taste and accompanied by a multitude of sauces and original side dishes. They highly recommend not overcooking your chosen steak, as South African meats are much lower in fat than meats in Europe and the US. Twenty tonnes of steak are served every month here. The menu also offers lamb, pork, and seafood, but takes little account of vegetarians.

An excellent choice of wines is on hand to accompany the great dishes. With panoramic views of the square, you'll feel like Johannesburg is right on your plate. Here the food is authentic and you can tell.

The Butcher Shop and Grill
Shop 30, Nelson Mandela Square
Sandton 2196

+27 (0)11 784 8676

www.thebutchershop.co.za

Menu: around 430 ZAR

content.title: AtholPlace Hotel & Villa: an oasis of tranquillity

introduction.small: A perfect address in the chic and cosmopolitan neighbourhood of Sandton.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: AtholPlace Hotel & Villa: an oasis of tranquillity

paragraphs.text:
Thanks to welcoming smiles, impeccable service, and a staff that knows when to appear and when to slip away, you will immediately be seduced by the atmosphere of this hotel of the Relais & Châteaux chain, their first in Johannesburg.

The nine suites are decorated in a warm mix of neutral, soothing, and natural tones, along with wood and wicker, and contemporary or African-inspired furnishings alongside a few well-chosen pieces of art. Each room is different and equipped with a private balcony. Depending on the time of day, you'll enjoy the large swimming pool that stretches out in the shade of a hedge of palms or the quiet of the magnificent library warmed by the fireplace for some cooler evenings.

The menu is renewed each day and you will feast on recipes with Asian and Indian influences prepared with excellent local produce, some straight from the herb garden on the property. Prepare yourself for a hushed and rejuvenating interlude in the heart of the city.

AtholPlace Hotel & Villa
90 Pretoria Avenue
Atholl
Johannesburg 2196

+27 (0)11 615 4303

http://morukuru.com/places/atholplacehotel/

Rooms: from 4,490 ZAR

content.title: Saxon Hotel: a well-kept secret

introduction.small: Voted the best boutique hotel in the world for six years in a row

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saxon Hotel: a well-kept secret

paragraphs.text:
The Saxon has been a veritable institution since, upon his release from prison, Nelson Mandela established residence here to write his autobiography. He could not have found a better symbol, as the hotel skilfully blends contemporary Western architecture with ethnic art. It is comfortable, warm, and unpretentious, even in the huge suite occupied by the father of the Rainbow Nation himself.

The hotel has 24 exclusive suites decorated in a subtle blend of modern and traditional African themes, with panoramic views of the garden and the city skyline. Zebra skins cover the wooden floors, and original paintings adorn the walls, including portraits of many South African leaders.

Its two restaurants serve cuisine prepared with organic seasonal ingredients. The hotel is located in a huge park with manicured lawns, a large swimming pool, and a great Spa that offers personalised treatments.

Saxon Hotel
36 Saxon Road
Sandhurst
Johannesburg 2196

+27 (0)11 292 6000

www.saxon.co.za

Rooms: from 7,135 ZAR

content.title: 44 Stanley: the anti-mall

introduction.small: Abandoned industrial buildings from the 1930s have been transformed into design studios, galleries, and restaurants.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 44 Stanley: the anti-mall

paragraphs.text:
Along Empire Road, a virtual border between the rich districts of the north and the poor neighbourhoods of the south, awaits an outdoor type of mall, with a very New York feel.

Brian Green bought this large complex of abandoned and dilapidated 1930s warehouses in 2003. The former film director rehabilitated them into a mini-village with a huge courtyard where trendy restaurants coexist with vanguard shops and street art. At 44 Stanley, you will only see local designers, shops, and restaurants, in contrast to many shopping centres dedicated to mass consumption. There are some lovely terraces here too.

A young clientele and families wander about the stalls or share a meal on a central square that brings Provence to mind. Make sure you see Jonathan Robinson: he roasts fair trade coffee on location that has been imported from several African countries, such as Ethiopia, Kenya, and Rwanda, among others.

44 Stanley
44 Stanley Avenue
Johannesburg 2092

+27 (0)11 482 4444

www.44stanley.co.za

content.title: Kruger Park: a safari in search of the ‘Big Five'

introduction.small: One of the most extraordinary nature reserves on the planet.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kruger Park: a safari in search of the ‘Big Five'

paragraphs.text:
A five-hour drive from Johannesburg, discover one of the largest game reserves in Africa, Kruger Park, which bears the name of its founder, Paul Kruger, a South African politician and a great defender of nature. A massive 350 kilometres long and 60 kilometres wide, these 20,000 square kilometres will give you an appointment with the famous ‘Big Five': lions, leopards, elephants, rhinos, and buffaloes. You will also find hyenas, hippos, giraffes, nyalas, and impalas. In all, 147 species of mammals, 500 varieties of birds, and 115 species of reptiles inhabit this Eden.

Today, more than 1 million visitors each year crisscross the 2 million hectares of the park and stay in one of 127 available lodges. Safaris set out every day with the famed open roofs. It is also possible to visit a small section of the Kruger Park on foot, but an armed ranger would need to accompany you.

South African National Parks
PO Box 787
Pretoria 0001

+27 (0)12 428 9111

www.sanparks.org/

content.title: Intercontinental Palazzo Montecasino: an Italian palace

introduction.small: A baroque-style palace and a mixture of styles bring the greatest pleasure to the senses.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Intercontinental Palazzo Montecasino: an Italian palace

paragraphs.text:
Africa has left the door open to Italian influences. The lounges and public areas of the Palazzo Montecasino mix Venetian chandeliers, delicate porcelain, and mirrors. The 231 rooms, 11 suites, and three apartments with terraces are all carefully decorated, the furniture is classic, and the fine fabrics bring a touch of preciousness to walls that play with pastel colours.

It is also in this same spirit that the hotel Spa was built. Just like a sanctuary, it offers an infinite range of spa treatments. For gastronomic pleasures, lunch is served in the Medeo restaurant, which celebrates Italian dishes with French and African influences. Light snacks are also offered in the relaxation area by the pool, surrounded by landscaped gardens.

Note that a bowling alley and a casino are also available on site. You will never get bored at the Palazzo!

Palazzo Montecasino
Montecasino Blvd
Johannesburg 2021

+27 (0)11 510 3000

www.tsogosun.com/the-palazzo-hotel

Rooms: from 3,525 ZAR

content.title: A hot-air balloon: a safari in the sky

introduction.small: A spectacular view from the air, from a starting point north of Johannesburg.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A hot-air balloon: a safari in the sky

paragraphs.text:
Why not explore the vast wilderness from lofty heights? One of the most eccentric characters of the region, Bill Harrop, flies daily at dawn from his site near Hartbeespoort Dam.

A huge colourful balloon rises gently into the sky at the same time as the sun does. Just climb into the wicker basket and a few minutes later, you will see Johannesburg in the distance and just below you, animals in the wild. Depending on the intensity of the wind and weather conditions, the balloon will float for about an hour, making this an original way to explore the city and the nearby wildlife. To complete the romance of this balloon trip, a breakfast with Champagne is served after landing.

Make sure you do not arrive late at the place of appointment, as the balloon will have taken off without you!

Bill Harrop's Original Balloon
R 560
Skeerpoort 2146

+27 (0)11 705 3201

www.balloon.co.za/

content.title: Pretoria: Afrikaner heritage and a newly named urban area

introduction.small: The former fiefdom of white domination has been renamed Tshwane, though the administrative area retains the name Pretoria. An indispensable stop on the quest to understanding the country's history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pretoria: Afrikaner heritage and a newly named urban area

paragraphs.text:
With its avenues lined with thousands of jacaranda trees and its imposing architecture, Pretoria remains a crucial place for understanding the political history of South Africa.

The administrative capital of the country includes important historical monuments such as the Union Building, the seat of government where Nelson Mandela gave his inaugural address in 1994, and the Voortrekker Monument, a tribute to Afrikaner history. Elsewhere, there is the courthouse, with its beautiful facade adorned with balconies, the location of Mandela's 1963 treason trial that ended with his life sentence. There is also the home of the iconic Paul Kruger, a former president of the Transvaal.

Among other things, Pretoria hosts the largest university in the country, the Pretoria Art Museum and its fine collection of traditional and contemporary art, and the National Zoological Gardens. This 80-hectare space is home to vast enclosures of more than 2,500 representatives of the local fauna, an aquarium, a vivarium, and a splendid collection of exotic trees.

content.title: Turn 'n Tender: real meat from a real family

introduction.small: Make the most of delicious steaks in a friendly atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Turn 'n Tender: real meat from a real family

paragraphs.text:
Founded by four brothers in 1977, this family institution now has eight establishments, including those in Parktown North, Bassonia, Illovo, and Bryanston.

They are known to offer the best choice of prime meats in Johannesburg. The house specialty remains the steak and you can try one of the four special variations created by the four brothers. You can also opt for any of a variety of cuts and specialty toppings, ranging from chimichurri, an Argentine marinade, to bordelaise or mushrooms and feta. You can also decide on pure beef burgers, ribs, lamb, game, or seafood. Don't miss the biltong, the South African dried and cured meat specialty. A rich wine list will highlight the flavours of your chosen meal.

The team is always ready to offer advice, with passion and professionalism, to the delight of numerous regulars. If you like meat, you are in the right place.

Turn'n Tender
Parktown Quarter
22 3rd Avenue
Johannesburg 2193

+27 (0)11 788 7933

https://turnntender.co.za

Menu: around 215 ZAR

content.title: The Maslow: an urban resort

introduction.small: A four-star hotel with the perfect balance for business or for pleasure.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Maslow: an urban resort

paragraphs.text:
Black, grey, and white décor, and contemporary design mark the Maslow, a hotel in the heart of the central business district of Sandton, where open spaces, clarity, and clean lines are the name of the game. The 281 rooms are divided into eight categories and have modern furnishings in warm colours.

Everything is designed to combine work and relaxation: this is a facility that will meet your expectations, whether you are travelling for business (there are business services, a conference centre, meeting rooms, and an auditorium) or you have come for pleasure (the Africology Spa, inspired by African wellness methods, the lounge bar, terraces, a swimming pool in a delightful urban garden, and a gym). All of this comes with a boutique hotel vibe in which you will feel totally at ease. Each suite offers panoramic city views.

In addition, Lacuna, the sophisticated urban bistro here, offers various fish and seafood dishes, as well as a good list of South African wines.

The Maslow Hotel Sandton
146 Rivonia Road
Sandton 2146

+27 (0)10 226 4600

www.suninternational.com/maslow/

Rooms: from 1,878 ZAR

content.title: Kim Sacks Gallery: Zulu art

introduction.small: A passionate artist dedicated to preserving the wealth of a civilisation that is disappearing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kim Sacks Gallery: Zulu art

paragraphs.text:
Founded by artist Kim Sacks, an accomplished ceramist who has travelled the world to study the craft, this amazing gallery showcases the work of local and international artists from all over Africa.

Here you will see a collection of ceramics and quality South African objects devoutly gathered by Sacks, who fights tirelessly for a civilization in great danger of dying. A woman with white skin but the heart of Zulu, steeped in passion and tenderness, Kim loves the creative genius of humanity.

Stop for a moment or for a few hours, and browse the extensive collection. Why not buy a unique piece of art? There are wooden carvings from the Congo, Zulu pottery, Mauritanian furniture, the threads and beads of South Africa, plus the textiles and ceramics of many artists on display here. A bright, peaceful, and harmonious space, it offers rare and unusual objects of great beauty.

Kim Sacks Gallery
153 Jan Smuts Avenue
Parkwood
Johannesburg 2193

+27 (0)11 447 5804

www.kimsacksgallery.com

content.title: Mall after mall: shopping in Johannesburg

introduction.small: Luxurious malls can be found throughout the city for shopping worthy of New York, London, or Paris.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mall after mall: shopping in Johannesburg

paragraphs.text:
In Johannesburg, the capital of consumption, you can indulge in endless shopping in malls that attract the wealthy from neighbouring African countries: the very chic Hyde Park, if you are looking for designer clothes and jewellery; Melrose Arch, full of pretty squares; Sandton City, a razzle dazzle choice; the gigantic Cresta Shopping Centre; the Rosebank Mall, where shops alternate with spacious terraces and outdoor cafes; and Ferndale on Republic where you will stroll among waterfalls and beautiful lawns.

Be aware that in terms of African crafts, the Rosebank Art & Craft Market takes the cake. For the best flea market, the Rosebank Sunday Market is renowned for clothing, ceramics, collectibles, used books, and jewellery. Rush to the Market Place if you are a CD or DVD collector. Finally, Bryanston Organic and Natural Market offers the best organic and natural products.

content.title: Singita Boulders: an extravagant lodge

introduction.small: Right next to Kruger Park, Singita is no hotel, but an authentic safari lodge ready to provide you with an experience only available in Africa.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Singita Boulders: an extravagant lodge

paragraphs.text:
Before becoming one of the most exclusive lodges in South Africa, Singita was a private home in the heart of the bush.

The concept: just a few beds in the largest possible surface area. Raised on stilts, 12 lodges of 100 square metres each overlook the Sabi Sand River, where, morning and evening, herds of elephants walk about on the sandbanks. The 12 suites combine contemporary safari style with luxury, while avoiding ostentation.

Inside, the living room, bedroom, and bathroom line up to form a graceful and sinuous flow, accented by fine woods, quality materials, and volcanic stones, while the exterior is built around a teak terrace. Everything here is ‘healthy and organic' save, perhaps, the extraordinary wine cellar of 3,000 bottles and 250 labels all set up for tastings. The romantic swimming pool, right under the trees, is also the setting where you will dine by candlelight. A stay here is one you will not soon forget!

Singita Boulders Lodge
Sabi Sand Private Game Reserve
Hazyview 1242

+27 (0)21 683 3424

https://singita.com

Rooms: from 28,840 ZAR

content.title: Maboneng Precinct and the MOAD: an island of hipness

introduction.small: Maboneng has followed the trajectory of many industrial zones in major world cities and is now home to a trendy neighbourhood of galleries, offices, lofts, restaurants, boutiques, and cafés.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maboneng Precinct and the MOAD: an island of hipness

paragraphs.text:
Abandoned to squatters and drug dealers in the late 1990s, the Maboneng district has been rejuvenated by a young entrepreneur who has spearheaded urban development and captured the attention of the youth of the city. Here you will find artists, creators, entrepreneurs, and designers in offices and workspaces, as well as in fashion boutiques alongside an avant-garde cinema and very popular restaurants. The new Museum of African Design (MOAD), in a 1970s-era warehouse, has an eclectic collection, from large abstract sculptures in rock or fibreglass to chairs in odd forms.

The museum aims to showcase artists of the highest level from the entire continent, though the majority of the 100 artists represented are native to South Africa. The district, frequented by hipsters and artists from the ‘born-free' generation, also claims to be the world capital of graffiti, one example of which is a massive Mandela in black, purple, and orange, with his fist raised.

You will discover another side of Johannesburg here, a side that brings together the cosmopolitan, avant-garde, and intellectual youth of the city of all ethnic backgrounds.

Museum of African Design (MOAD)
281 Commissioner Street
Johannesburg 2094

+27 (0)10 500 2448

www.artsy.net/moadjhb

content.title: Museum Africa: national history on display

introduction.small: A museum that treats the history and culture of the country with panache.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museum Africa: national history on display

paragraphs.text:
Located in the halls of a former fruit and vegetable market in the Newlands, Museum Africa, dedicated to the social and cultural history of South Africa, features vaulted exhibition spaces that occupy an entire block. Through its paintings, photographs, and wonderful exhibits, take a journey that fascinates both children and adults curious to learn more about the industrial heritage, culture, and history of the country. Want a preview of what you find here?

The history of Gauteng and Johannesburg, the first sites in the discovery of gold, plus reconstructions of townships and the interiors of residences. There are also presentations of South African music, with its most representative instruments, photography and cinema, and cave art in a reconstructed cavern. Another area is dedicated to Gandhi's life in Johannesburg and yet another on the historic 1956 trial of anti-apartheid militants.

Museum Africa
Lilian Ngoyi Street
Johannesburg 2000

+27 (0)11 833 5624

https://www.gauteng.net/attractions/attraction-museum-africa-jiyp

content.title: From Constitution Hill to Carlton Centre

introduction.small: Visit the vestiges of colonial South Africa on Constitution Hill before heading up to the top floor of the city's tallest building for a breath-taking 360º view of Johannesburg.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: From Constitution Hill to Carlton Centre

paragraphs.text:
In the area of Johannesburg called Braamfontein, Constitution Hill contains a collection of modern and historical buildings. The Old Fort Prison is a former military fort that had become a prison, primarily for white prisoners; it is now a museum. The ‘Number Four' section contained more than 2,200 prisoners in a space constructed for 979 including famous ‘guests' like Nelson and Winnie Mandela, and Gandhi. Also to be found are the Constitutional Hall, a courthouse with contemporary public art and the Constitutional Court, the highest court of law in the country.

A 15-minute drive away on Commissioner Street, the Carlton Centre, with its 50 floors, can be spotted from a distance. It houses a mall and a panoramic bar, called Top of Africa, and a rooftop terrace, overlooking the city lights, that can accommodate up to 450 guests for an elegant dinner, concert, or fashion show. Be aware that visits on foot are best for the daytime as the streets empty very quickly on Constitution Hill in the late afternoon and evening.

Constitution Hill
11 Kotze Street
Braamfontein
Johannesburg 2107

+27 (0)11 381 3100

www.constitutionhill.org.za

content.title: Goodman Gallery: the reference

introduction.small: For several decades, this gallery has been the place to see both new and acclaimed artists.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Goodman Gallery: the reference

paragraphs.text:
At the forefront of contemporary art in South Africa, the Goodman Gallery showcases South African artists, while including others from across the continent. Founded in 1966, at the time of apartheid, in the Parkwood neighbourhood by Linda Goodman, the gallery played a considerable role in the emergence of young black artists who were then denied access to galleries and museums.

Photography from the apartheid era was synonymous with political struggle. The artists of the country were engaged in a radical fight against segregationist policies, using art as their weapon. Through their testimonies and art works, they tried to counter the inequality. The top South African photographer, David Goldblatt, represented by the Goodman Gallery, has put his country on film, especially the city of Johannesburg.

Do not hesitate to discover the Goodman; the contemporary South African photography scene is now one of the most dynamic in the world, and its representatives have gained international recognition. Rightly so.

Goodman Gallery
163 Jan Smuts Avenue
Johannesburg 2193

+27 (0)11 788 1113

www.goodman-gallery.com

content.title: Gold Reef City: a rush for fun and amusement

introduction.small: This gigantic theme park highlights the gold miners of yesteryear.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gold Reef City: a rush for fun and amusement

paragraphs.text:
Just five kilometres to the south-west of downtown Johannesburg is Gold Reef City (where the Apartheid Museum is also found).

Gold Reef City is a tribute to what made the prosperity of the city: the ‘gold reef', a vein of gold that extends from east to west, just south of the city, of which remains are still visible. The park takes you to the Johannesburg of early 1900s, to the days of the gold diggers. This theme park is built around a real mineshaft, 2,393 metres deep, that produced over 1,400 tonnes of gold before its closure in 1971. The guided tour takes you 220 metres underground and reveals the working conditions of miners in the tunnels, where there was stifling heat and a lack of oxygen.

On the surface, a mining camp lets you witness the processing of this precious bullion.

Gold Reef City
Northern Parkway & Data Crescent
Johannesburg 2159

+27 (0)11 461 9744

www.tsogosun.com/gold-reef-city-casino

content.title: The Apartheid Museum, memory lives on

introduction.small: Take the time to understand what ‘separateness', the translation of the word ‘apartheid', really means.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Apartheid Museum, memory lives on

paragraphs.text:
Apartheid was just yesterday, and to help you realize the significance of that, a visit to this museum is very worthwhile. Take in the exceptional work of historians, architects, and filmmakers offering a deeply immersive vision of the world of institutionalized segregation.

As soon as you enter, you will be assigned, at random, a “skin colour” that will determine the entrance you use, either white or non-white. The tour then follows a chronological order with the emergence of the National Party, which introduced apartheid in 1948, the rise of black resistance, ruthless repression, and political executions, all of which ended with the first democratic elections by the entire population in 1994.

The aesthetic quality of the photos and videos, the replicas of the isolation cells, and the abundance of documentary materials contribute to the emotional power of this place you will feel drawn into the story, so close and yet so far. This is a place of remarkably well-orchestrated storytelling that makes manifest its slogan: 'Apartheid has a place. In a museum.

Apartheid Museum
Northern Park Way & Gold Reef Road
Johannesburg 2001

+27 (0)11 309 4700

www.apartheidmuseum.org

content.title: David Krut Projects: front-row culture

introduction.small: Bookstore, exhibition space, print workshop, and more, the alternative arts institution David Krut Projects works with contemporary South African art and artists in myriad ways.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: David Krut Projects: front-row culture

paragraphs.text:
Renowned for its temporary exhibitions and its many art publications available in limited editions, the David Krut Projects arts initiative, which now has a New York branch, allows you to take the pulse of the arts scene while deepening your African cultural knowledge.

The organization has an experimental workshop, the David Krut Print Workshop, in which artists can create freely: Among those who have worked here are Wiliam Kentridge, Deborah Bell, Mongezi Ncaphayi, Jaco van Schalkwyk, Diane Victor, Mary Wafer, Senzo Shabangu, Stephen Hobbs, Maja Maljevic, Robyn Penn, Jürgen Partenheimer and Locust Jones.

Interest in South African art is growing, thanks to the work of the Museum of Contemporary Art Africa, which focuses on contemporary artists and supports collections, which was far from the case in the past. The relaxed atmosphere of this elegant place of creation is particularly popular with the trendy minds of Johannesburg.

David Krut Projects
151 Jan Smuts Avenue
Johannesburg 2193

+27 (0)11 447 0627

https://davidkrutprojects.com

content.title: Seeing Johannesburg: family-friendly visiting

introduction.small: Fun and amusing ways to see Johannesburg that will please all ages.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Seeing Johannesburg: family-friendly visiting

paragraphs.text:
Children love the red City Sightseeing double decker bus, which makes stops around the city, but the journey is just as fun for adults. It's a simple and secure means of transport that allows you to spend time in places like Constitution Hill, the Gold Reef City theme park, and the Origins Centre museum, which traces the history of mankind. You can also climb to the Top of Africa, the last floor of the Carlton Tower, the tallest tower on the African continent, for a stunning view of the city.

Start your trip at the Gautrain Park station or at the Gold Reef City theme park, where you can park all day for free if you join the City Sightseeing tour.

On another day, you can take younger children to the Moyo restaurant at Zoo Lake, which offers loads of activities in an exceptional setting. Children can feed the ducks, cross the lake rowing a boat, or play in the playground. Teens may like the guided tours of Newtown, organised by Past Experiences, particularly for the street culture and graffiti.

Past Experiences

+27 (0)83 701 3046

https://pastexperiences.co.za

content.title: Soweto: victory against apartheid

introduction.small: The township that is a historical symbol of the fall of apartheid has now become a truly modern city with trendy restaurants and a huge shopping centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Soweto: victory against apartheid

paragraphs.text:
Designated by its geographical position in the south-west of the city, South West Township (So-we-to) remains the historic district that saw the rise of the ANC, Mandela, and Desmond Tutu, and the fall of apartheid. This renowned township is a place of memory today and you can visit with different tour operators who will show you the sites on a bicycle or in a bus. The house where Nelson Mandela lived in 1962, before his decades-long imprisonment, has now become a museum.

Strolling before the pictures, and among the Spartan furniture and everyday objects, you take in the fragments of a poignant saga and can perhaps imagine the family taking refuge under a table while police launch tear gas outside. Just a few metres away, the villa of Desmond Tutu neighbours that of Winnie Mandela.

To add to this concentration of history, visit the Hector Pieterson Memorial and Museum, named after the 12-year-old schoolboy who was shot in the back during the events of 1976 known as the ‘Soweto Uprising' or ‘16 June'. That day, the police fired on the crowd, killing 23 people. This tragedy marked the beginning of the end of apartheid.

Mandela House
8115 Vilakazi Street & Ngakane Street
Johannesburg 1804

+27 (0)11 936 7754

www.mandelahouse.com
